Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research - Strategies: GLOBE California Academy Program (CAP) ITEST Strategy Grant

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
WestEd and the University of California-Berkeley are improving student learning and workforce preparation in science as well as information and communication technology by embedding the Global Learning and Observations to Benefit the Environment (GLOBE) program into curricula of selected high school-level green energy career academies in California. Embedding GLOBE within California's green energy academies will pave the way for broader GLOBE implementation in California and other states.

The GLOBE California Academy Program (CAP) is engaging students, particularly at-risk students, in research related to climate science and renewable energy technologies, providing professional development and support for academy teachers, connecting scientists and industry to academy classrooms, and linking students to GLOBE's international student community. GLOBE's data collection and analysis activities will become an integral and sustainable part of a rigorous inquiry-based approach to science education that prepares students for postsecondary education and science careers.

Integrating GLOBE into CAP will produce a replicable model program that improves high school students' preparation for postsecondary education and careers in science and technology fields. Outcomes for students include improved science/technology knowledge and skills, higher grades, increased interest in pursuing postsecondary education and science/technology careers, and development of 21st century workforce skills. Outcomes for teachers include increased facility with GLOBE and scientific practice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
WestEd and the College and Career Academy Support Network (CCASN) at UC Berkeley received a three-year collaborative ITEST strategy grant to improve learning and workforce development in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) and in information and communication technology (ICT) — especially for underserved students. The strategy integrated the hands-on science pedagogy of the Global Learning and Observations to Benefit the Environment (GLOBE) program into the multi-year curricula of California green (environmental) high school career academies — “schools within schools” that focus on the renewable energy and clean technology sector. The GLOBE California Academy Program (CAP) engaged students in data collection and research related to the environment and climate change and supported the academy teachers with professional development and ongoing technical assistance. The fusion of GLOBE and CAP was designed to produce a sustainable and replicable model to improve high school students’ preparation for postsecondary education and careers in STEM fields.

The program sought to build skills and motivate students over their three year academy participation, with the first year focused on data collection, the second year on data visualization and interpretation, and the third year on application of learning in a community-based project.  Throughout, students were exposed to STEM careers.

The program partnered with the Berkeley Atmospheric Science Center at UC Berkeley, whose director and graduate students engaged systematically with GLOBE CAP students, sharing information about their projects, presenting “real world” guidance about science practices such as the importance of precision and accuracy, assisting with GLOBE data collection, and discussing their education and careers as scientists. It also partnered with the UC Berkeley Center for Cities and Schools to implement the Y-PLAN (Youth Plan

Learn Act Now) methodology in the 12th grade civic engagement component.

Results. GLOBE CAP has shown promising results. The evaluation showed significant differences in participating students’ course taking in science and math and in Advance Placement course taking compared with non-participants in the same schools, and 11th graders taking the math Smarter Balanced assessment did better than comparison students. Students also showed increases in science-related attitudes, especially enjoyment of science. Overall, teachers attributed the GLOBE program with providing their students greater knowledge, skills, and abilities related to STEM, for example understanding the importance of consistent and reliable data collection, developing the skills to use rigorous data collection methods, and possessing knowledge and experience analyzing data. In addition, teachers showed growth in facility with the GLOBE protocols and activities. The three-year structure of the academies also facilitated sustainability, as teachers supported one another from grade to grade and responded as a team to teacher turnover. Teachers also expressed commitment to continued implementation.
